commit_message:
Remove dup of LibvirtISCSIVolumeDriver in LibvirtISERVolumeDriver

LibvirtISERVolumeDriver is an almost copy of
LibvirtISCSIVolumeDriver.

Change-Id: I7f71be69df6dc203508114fc67f55b7da2b0e529
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/55/46055/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: host_device = self._get_host_device(iscsi_properties) self._reconnect(iscsi_properties) def _get_host_device(self, iscsi_properties): return ("/dev/disk/by-path/ip-%s-iscsi-%s-lun-%s" % (iscsi_properties['target_portal'], iscsi_properties['target_iqn'], iscsi_properties.get('target_lun', 0))) def _reconnect(self, iscsi_properties): self._run_iscsiadm(iscsi_properties, ('--op', 'new')) def _get_host_device(self, iser_properties): time.sleep(1) host_device = None device = ("ip-%s-iscsi-%s-lun-%s" % (iser_properties['target_portal'], iser_properties['target_iqn'], iser_properties.get('target_lun', 0))) look_for_device = glob.glob('/dev/disk/by-path/*%s' % device) if look_for_device: host_device = look_for_device[0] return host_device def _reconnect(self, iser_properties): self._run_iscsiadm(iser_properties, ('--interface', 'iser', '--op', 'new'))
deleted_lines: cfg.IntOpt('num_iser_scan_tries', default=3, help='number of times to rescan iSER target to find volume'), cfg.BoolOpt('libvirt_iser_use_multipath', default=False, help='use multipath connection of the iSER volume'), host_device = ("/dev/disk/by-path/ip-%s-iscsi-%s-lun-%s" % (iscsi_properties['target_portal'], iscsi_properties['target_iqn'], iscsi_properties.get('target_lun', 0))) self._run_iscsiadm(iscsi_properties, ('--op', 'new')) @utils.synchronized('connect_volume') def connect_volume(self, connection_info, disk_info): """Attach the volume to instance_name.""" conf = LibvirtBaseVolumeDriver.connect_volume(self, connection_info, disk_info) iser_properties = connection_info['data'] libvirt_iser_use_multipath = CONF.libvirt_iser_use_multipath if libvirt_iser_use_multipath: # multipath installed, discovering other targets if available # multipath should be configured on the nova-compute node, # in order to fit storage vendor out = self._run_iscsiadm_bare(['-m', 'discovery', '-t', 'sendtargets', '-p', iser_properties['target_portal']], check_exit_code=[0, 255])[0] or "" for ip in self._get_target_portals_from_iscsiadm_output(out): props = iser_properties.copy() props['target_portal'] = ip self._connect_to_iser_portal(props) self._rescan_iscsi() else: self._connect_to_iser_portal(iser_properties) time.sleep(1) host_device = None device = ("ip-%s-iscsi-%s-lun-%s" % (iser_properties['target_portal'], iser_properties['target_iqn'], iser_properties.get('target_lun', 0))) look_for_device = glob.glob('/dev/disk/by-path/*%s' % device) if look_for_device: host_device = look_for_device[0] # The /dev/disk/by-path/... node is not always present immediately tries = 0 disk_dev = disk_info['dev'] while not os.path.exists(host_device): if tries >= CONF.num_iser_scan_tries: raise exception.NovaException(_("iSER device not found at %s") % host_device) LOG.warn(_("ISER volume not yet found at: %(disk_dev)s. " "Will rescan & retry. Try number: %(tries)s") % {'disk_dev': disk_dev, 'tries': tries}) # The rescan isn't documented as being necessary(?), but it helps self._run_iscsiadm(iser_properties, ("--rescan",)) tries = tries + 1 if not os.path.exists(host_device): time.sleep(tries ** 2) if tries != 0: LOG.debug(_("Found iSER node %(disk_dev)s " "(after %(tries)s rescans)") % {'disk_dev': disk_dev, 'tries': tries}) if libvirt_iser_use_multipath: # we use the multipath device instead of the single path device self._rescan_multipath() multipath_device = self._get_multipath_device_name(host_device) if multipath_device is not None: host_device = multipath_device conf.source_type = "block" conf.source_path = host_device return conf @utils.synchronized('connect_volume') def disconnect_volume(self, connection_info, disk_dev): """Detach the volume from instance_name.""" iser_properties = connection_info['data'] multipath_device = None if CONF.libvirt_iser_use_multipath: host_device = ("/dev/disk/by-path/ip-%s-iscsi-%s-lun-%s" % (iser_properties['target_portal'], iser_properties['target_iqn'], iser_properties.get('target_lun', 0))) multipath_device = self._get_multipath_device_name(host_device) LibvirtBaseVolumeDriver.disconnect_volume(self, connection_info, disk_dev) if CONF.libvirt_iser_use_multipath and multipath_device: return self._disconnect_volume_multipath_iscsi(iser_properties) # NOTE(vish): Only disconnect from the target if no luns from the # target are in use. device_prefix = ("/dev/disk/by-path/ip-%s-iscsi-%s-lun-" % (iser_properties['target_portal'], iser_properties['target_iqn'])) devices = self.connection.get_all_block_devices() devices = [dev for dev in devices if dev.startswith(device_prefix)] if not devices: self._disconnect_from_iscsi_portal(iser_properties) def _connect_to_iser_portal(self, iser_properties): # NOTE(vish): If we are on the same host as nova volume, the # discovery makes the target so we don't need to # run --op new. Therefore, we check to see if the # target exists, and if we get 255 (Not Found), then # we run --op new. This will also happen if another # volume is using the same target. try: self._run_iscsiadm(iser_properties, ()) except processutils.ProcessExecutionError as exc: # iscsiadm returns 21 for "No records found" after version 2.0-871 if exc.exit_code in [21, 255]: self._run_iscsiadm(iser_properties, ('--interface', 'iser', '--op', 'new')) else: raise if iser_properties.get('auth_method'): self._iscsiadm_update(iser_properties, "node.session.auth.authmethod", iser_properties['auth_method']) self._iscsiadm_update(iser_properties, "node.session.auth.username", iser_properties['auth_username']) self._iscsiadm_update(iser_properties, "node.session.auth.password", iser_properties['auth_password']) self._iscsiadm_update(iser_properties, "iface.transport_name", "iser") # duplicate logins crash iscsiadm after load, # so we scan active sessions to see if the node is logged in. out = self._run_iscsiadm_bare(["-m", "session"], run_as_root=True, check_exit_code=[0, 1, 21])[0] or "" portals = [{'portal': p.split(" ")[2], 'iqn': p.split(" ")[3]} for p in out.splitlines() if p.startswith("iser:")] stripped_portal = iser_properties['target_portal'].split(",")[0] filtered_portal = [s for s in portals if stripped_portal == s['portal'].split(",")[0] and s['iqn'] == iser_properties['target_iqn']] if len(portals) == 0 or len(filtered_portal) == 0: try: self._run_iscsiadm(iser_properties, ("--login",), check_exit_code=[0, 255]) except processutils.ProcessExecutionError as err: # as this might be one of many paths, # only set successfull logins to startup automatically if err.exit_code == 15: self._iscsiadm_update(iser_properties, "node.startup", "automatic") return self._iscsiadm_update(iser_properties, "node.startup", "automatic")

commit_message:
Test image member is enforced

* Testing is an image member able to get the image
* Testing the image is invisible for not member tenants
* Moving negative tests into a new file
* Using uuid for random ids

replace assertEquals with assertEqual

assertEquals will be deprecated in Python 3.

This is part of blueprint assertequal

Closes loose ends and adds pep8 enforecment.

Change-Id: Ib6181873a33dbe54660eeb031f7cea53f7f75608

commit_message:
Flatten hypervisor-show dictionary for printing

Flatten the nested dicts so that hypervisor information can be more
easily used at the command line.

Change-Id: I5dfcf9d10f917a63bde09f0b5a691784a5e8f02b
Closes-bug: #1243512
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/65/53265/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import jsondef _flatten(name, value): """Flatten a dict, using name as a prefix for the keys of dict. >>> _flatten('cpu_info', {'arch':'x86_64'}) [('cpu_info_arch': 'x86_64')] """ items = [] if isinstance(value, dict): for key, v in value.items(): n = name + '_' + key if isinstance(v, six.string_types): items.append((n, v)) else: items.extend(_flatten(n, v)) elif isinstance(value, list): # if it's a nested list then the best we can do is convert it # to a string. items.append((name, ', '.join([str(v) for v in value]))) else: items.append((name, value)) return items def flatten_dict(d): """Flatten a nested python dict out into it's components. Appending each of the parents keys. Any string elements will be JSON parsed before flattening. >>> flatten_dict({'service': {'host':'cloud9@compute-068', 'id': 143}}) {'service_host': colud9@compute-068', 'service_id': 143} """ items = [] for k, v in d.items(): if isinstance(v, six.string_types): try: v = json.loads(v) except: pass items.extend(_flatten(k, v)) return dict(items)

commit_message:
Adds basic plumbing for RESTful API service

This patch adds some basic plumbing for a Solum RESTful
API service. It uses the excellent and simple Falcon library
as its WSGI pipeline processing and route handling. Included
is a simple VersionsResource and a few serialization helpers
along with tests that cover all of the added code. Hoping that
this patch will spark some discussions around how to approach
building the API service.

addresses blueprint rest-api-base

Change-Id: I7c8f62f09d1555b4375abad049055ae0f2658169

added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2013 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import logging from fuel_health import ceilometeramnager LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class CeilometerApiTests(ceilometeramnager.CeilometerBaseTest): """ TestClass contains tests that check basic Compute functionality. """ def test_list_meters(self): """list availability Test checks that the list of resources, meters, alarms is available. Target component: Ceilometer Scenario: 1. Request the list of meters 2. Request the list of alarms 3. Request the list of resources. Duration: 5 s. """ fail_msg = "meter list unavailable" list_meters_resp = self.verify(20, self.list_meters, 1, fail_msg, "meter listing") fail_msg = "alarm list unavailable" list_alarms_resp = self.verify(20, self.list_alarm, 1, fail_msg, "alarm listing") fail_msg = 'Resource list is unavailable. ' list_resources_resp = self.verify(5, self.list_resources, 1, fail_msg, "resource listing")

subject: Remove nose from requirements list
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-06 09:10:18.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/stress/run_stress.py', 'run_tests.sh', 'requirements.txt', 'tox.ini', 'tempest/test.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/f024126c447cd08fe6f785206d6740d60c815277', 'message': 'Remove nose from requirements list

This commit removes nose from the requirements list. The issues with
python 2.6 and testr should go away if we move to using unittest2
instead of unittest. So there is no reason to use nose ever!!

Change-Id: I08de2a42e04b91531d6bfef8c3600a98a760c77a
'}]
commit_message:
Remove nose from requirements list

This commit removes nose from the requirements list. The issues with
python 2.6 and testr should go away if we move to using unittest2
instead of unittest. So there is no reason to use nose ever!!

Change-Id: I08de2a42e04b91531d6bfef8c3600a98a760c77a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/74/55374/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # there is a mis-match between nose and testtools for older pythons. # testtools will set skipException to be either # unittest.case.SkipTest, unittest2.case.SkipTest or an internal skip # exception, depending on what it can find. Python <2.7 doesn't have # unittest.case.SkipTest; so if unittest2 is not installed it falls # back to the internal class. # # The current nose skip plugin will decide to raise either # unittest.case.SkipTest or its own internal exception; it does not # look for unittest2 or the internal unittest exception. Thus we must # monkey-patch testtools.TestCase.skipException to be the exception # the nose skip plugin expects. # # However, with the switch to testr nose may not be available, so we # require you to opt-in to this fix with an environment variable. # # This is temporary until upstream nose starts looking for unittest2 # as testtools does; we can then remove this and ensure unittest2 is # available for older pythons; then nose and testtools will agree # unittest2.case.SkipTest is the one-true skip test exception. # # https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33056 # https://github.com/nose-devs/nose/pull/699 if 'TEMPEST_PY26_NOSE_COMPAT' in os.environ: try: import unittest.case.SkipTest # convince pep8 we're using the import... if unittest.case.SkipTest: pass raise RuntimeError("You have unittest.case.SkipTest; " "no need to override") except ImportError: LOG.info("Overriding skipException to nose SkipTest") testtools.TestCase.skipException = nose.plugins.skip.SkipTest

subject: Make vm cleaner script more flexible
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-23 14:29:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/72f43fc9fb21405d6171800ad9095dcca788a9ce', 'message': 'Make vm cleaner script more flexible

Adds a few options to vm_vdi_cleaner to make it
more flexible.
-Divide orphans into types "deleting" and "zombie"
 *deleting refers to instances stuck in task_state "deleting" and
  vm_state "active"
 *zombies refer to instances that are deleted but are running on
  the HV
-Allow shutting down orphaned instances as an option other than delete

Change-Id: Ie8599d05313e7853c8fe99fda72a54d14b897d65

 *zombies refer to instances that are deleted but are running on
  the HV
-Allow shutting down orphaned instances as an option other than delete

Change-Id: Ie8599d05313e7853c8fe99fda72a54d14b897d65
'}]
commit_message:
Make vm cleaner script more flexible

Adds a few options to vm_vdi_cleaner to make it
more flexible.
-Divide orphans into types "deleting" and "zombie"
 *deleting refers to instances stuck in task_state "deleting" and
  vm_state "active"
 *zombies refer to instances that are deleted but are running on
  the HV
-Allow shutting down orphaned instances as an option other than delete

Change-Id: Ie8599d05313e7853c8fe99fda72a54d14b897d65
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/62/53362/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """ vm_vdi_cleaner.py - List or clean orphaned VDIs/instances on XenServer. Instances that are considered orphans are of two types: "deleting" - instance that is in status "active" and task_state "deleting" "zombie" - instance that has been "deleted" but still running on the HV """cli_opts = [cfg.StrOpt('command', default=None, help='Cleaner command'), cfg.StrOpt('type', default='all', help='type of orphan instance [zombie|deleting]'), ]CONF.register_cli_opts(cli_opts) "clean-instances", "shutdown-instances", "test"] active_and_deleting = [] zombie_instances = [] instance = db.api.instance_get_by_uuid(ctxt, uuid) except (KeyError, exception.InstanceNotFound): # NOTE(sulo): We print if there is any exception, but # take no action on those instances because those could be legit # active running instances or instances we dont know about, so ignore. is_active_and_deleting = (instance['vm_state'] == "active" and instance['task_state'] == "deleting") # NOTE(sulo): A zombie VM is an instance that has been deleted but # still running on the HV. is_zombie_vm = (instance['vm_state'] == "deleted" and instance['power_state'] not in [4, 7]) if is_active_and_deleting: active_and_deleting.append((vm_ref, vm_rec, instance)) if is_zombie_vm: zombie_instances.append((vm_ref, vm_rec, instance)) return active_and_deleting, zombie_instances def shutdown_instance(xenapi, instance, vm_ref, vm_rec): """Shutdown orphaned instance.""" try: xenapi._vmops.power_off(instance) except XenAPI.Failure as error: print "Error shuttingdown instance: %s %s" % (instance['name'], error) """Delete orphaned instance.""" try: xenapi._vmops._destroy(instance, vm_ref) except XenAPI.Failure as error: print "Error destroying instance %s %s" % (instance['name'], error) if vm_rec["is_a_template"] or vm_rec["is_control_domain"] \ or vm_rec["name_label"] == "compute": print "ORPHANED INSTANCE (%s)" % orphaned_instance['name'] else: print orphaned_instance['name']def shutdown_orphaned_instances(xenapi, orphaned_instances): """Shutdown orphaned instances.""" for vm_ref, vm_rec, instance in orphaned_instances: # Skip shutdown if the vm is already powered off if vm_rec["power_state"] == "Halted": continue if CONF.verbose: print "SHUTTING DOWN ORPHAN INSTANCE (%s)" % instance['name'] shutdown_instance(xenapi, instance, vm_ref, vm_rec) def get_instance_type(xenapi): """Get list of given instance type.""" deleting_vms, zombie_vms = find_orphaned_instances(xenapi) instances = [] instance_type = CONF.type if instance_type == "all": instances = deleting_vms + zombie_vms elif instance_type in ["zombies", "zombie"]: instances = zombie_vms elif instance_type == "deleting": instances = deleting_vms if not instances: # User gave wrong instance type return None return instances orphaned_instances = get_instance_type(xenapi) if orphaned_instances: list_orphaned_instances(orphaned_instances) else: print "No orphaned instance of type %s found" % CONF.type elif command == "clean-instances": orphaned_instances = get_instance_type(xenapi) if orphaned_instances: clean_orphaned_instances(xenapi, orphaned_instances) else: print "No instnace of type: %s found for cleaning" % CONF.type elif command == "shutdown-instances": orphaned_instances = get_instance_type(xenapi) if orphaned_instances: shutdown_orphaned_instances(xenapi, orphaned_instances) else: print "No instance of type: %s found for shutdown" % CONF.type
deleted_lines: """vm_vdi_cleaner.py - List or clean orphaned VDIs/instances on XenServer."""cli_opt = cfg.StrOpt('command', help='Cleaner command')CONF.register_cli_opt(cli_opt) "clean-instances", "test"] orphaned_instances = [] instance = db.instance_get_by_uuid(ctxt, uuid) except (KeyError, exception.InstanceNotFound): # NOTE(jk0): Err on the side of caution here. If we don't know # anything about the particular instance, ignore it. is_active_and_deleting = (instance.vm_state == "active" and instance.task_state == "deleting") # NOTE(jk0): A zombie VM is an instance that is not active and hasn't # been updated in over the specified period. is_zombie_vm = (instance.vm_state != "active" and timeutils.is_older_than(instance.updated_at, CONF.zombie_instance_updated_at_window)) if is_active_and_deleting or is_zombie_vm: orphaned_instances.append((vm_ref, vm_rec, instance)) return orphaned_instances """Delete orphaned instances.""" xenapi._vmops._destroy(instance, vm_ref) if vm_rec["is_a_template"] or vm_rec["is_control_domain"]: print "ORPHANED INSTANCE (%s)" % orphaned_instance.name else: print orphaned_instance.name orphaned_instances = find_orphaned_instances(xenapi) list_orphaned_instances(orphaned_instances) elif command == "clean-instances": orphaned_instances = find_orphaned_instances(xenapi) clean_orphaned_instances(xenapi, orphaned_instances)

commit_message:
add some tests for quota set operation

add some tests for quota set operation and seperate negative testcases
into a dedicated file according to
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/tempest/HACKING.html#negative-tests

Change-Id: I530654220f458cd5923d1d0e09f8056dcd2503da
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/34/50234/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # normal user can get the default resource quota set for the tenant # he belongs to. @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_get_other_tenant_quotas_with_normal_user(self): # Normal user couldn't get other tenants' quota set tenant_name = rand_name('quota_other_tenant_') tenant_desc = tenant_name + '-desc' identity_client = self.os_adm.identity_client _, tenant = identity_client.create_tenant(name=tenant_name, description=tenant_desc) tenant_id = tenant['id'] self.addCleanup(identity_client.delete_tenant, tenant_id) self.assertRaises(exceptions.Unauthorized, self.client.get_quota_set, tenant_id) @attr(type='gate') def test_get_other_tenant_quotas_with_admin(self): # Admin can get the resource quota set for a tenant expected_quota_set = self.default_quota_set | set(['id']) resp, quota_set = self.client.get_quota_set(self.demo_tenant_id) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status) self.assertEqual(sorted(expected_quota_set), sorted(quota_set.keys())) self.assertEqual(quota_set['id'], self.demo_tenant_id) def test_update_quota_invalid_ram_value(self): self.assertRaises(exceptions.BadRequest, self.adm_client.update_quota_set, self.demo_tenant_id, ram='invalid') @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_update_quota_less_than_minimum(self): # Create a server resp, server = self.create_server(wait_until='ACTIVE') self.assertEqual(202, resp.status) self.assertRaises(exceptions.BadRequest, self.adm_client.update_quota_set, self.demo_tenant_id, instances=0) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_delete_quota_with_normal_user(self): # Normal user couldn't delete quota set self.assertRaises(exceptions.Unauthorized, self.client.delete_quota_set, self.demo_tenant_id) @attr(type='gate') def test_delete_quota_with_admin(self): # Admin can delete quota set for a tenant tenant_name = rand_name('delete_quota_tenant_') tenant_desc = tenant_name + '-desc' _, tenant = self.identity_admin_client. \ create_tenant(name=tenant_name, description=tenant_desc) tenant_id = tenant['id'] self.addCleanup(self.identity_admin_client.delete_tenant, tenant_id) resp, body = self.adm_client.delete_quota_set(tenant_id) self.assertEqual(202, resp.status)
deleted_lines: # Admin can get the default resource quota set for a tenant

commit_message:
feat(controller) : Implement Queue Controller

This patchset contributes a queue controller for Marconi client.
Allows getting messages, claiming messages, updating claims & releasing
them as well returning queue names and metadata.

Change-Id: I5ad6972d9f6419800df6f8bd8713e80cf64438a2
Implements: blueprint queues-management

commit_message:
Remove the use of common.uuidutils.gen_uuid

There's a movement to remove gen_uuid from the
openstack common.  This change removes it's use
from Cinder and just puts the call inline.

Change-Id: I07329bab9553e15e498ddbda3848d50b8f48fd53

commit_message:
Install Guide: service fixes for ubuntu on neutron installation

* Open vSwitch needs a restart after the datapath module installation
* Debian/Ubuntu don't use chkconfig

Change-Id: I08519e60bcc301d49a3e3f2a33e1980f763cecdf
backport: havana

commit_message:
Install Guide: make sure that the admin can use the nova command

The first nova command example might be executed on a compute node by
the user, and it's likely that python-novaclient has not been installed
there. Suggest to the user to log on the controller or to install the
client.

Change-Id: I57009deb4a817966f9a37036f3230a418a5133e3
Partial-Bug: #1245946
backport: havana

commit_message:
Refresh Cloud Server data for RackConnect check

Refresh Cloud Server data on each iteration of check_create_complete to
ensure the server metadata is up-to-date for the RackConnect check and
any subsequent checks.

Change-Id: Ia4ad04cfd5e76b639a0b98c21e381db70551090a
Closes-bug: #1250647

subject: Ensure autoscaling actions occur for percentage adjustment
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-13 20:55:13.000000000', 'files': ['heat/engine/resources/autoscaling.py', 'heat/tests/test_autoscaling.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/5720e6d647ce3a273d638fd7dacc9c2d6eb2bc22', 'message': 'Ensure autoscaling actions occur for percentage adjustment

Fixes bug 1251007

Previously if the AdjustmentType was set to PercentChangeInCapacity,
then depending on the choice of the instance group MinSize and the
scale-up policy ScalingAdjustment, no autoscaling actions may occur
even when the under-scaled alarm fires.

This situation occurred if:

   (MinSize * ScalingAdjustment / 100.0) < 1.0

in which case the group never get gets scaled up even if the under-
scaled alarm stays in the alarm state forever.

Now we follow the rounding rules used by AWS Autoscaling:

  http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AutoScaling/latest/DeveloperGuide/as-scale-based-on-demand.html

Change-Id: I79e5e743de1944ace5ef2c4dbcb76c9cab7262bb
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure autoscaling actions occur for percentage adjustment

Fixes bug 1251007

Previously if the AdjustmentType was set to PercentChangeInCapacity,
then depending on the choice of the instance group MinSize and the
scale-up policy ScalingAdjustment, no autoscaling actions may occur
even when the under-scaled alarm fires.

This situation occurred if:

   (MinSize * ScalingAdjustment / 100.0) < 1.0

in which case the group never get gets scaled up even if the under-
scaled alarm stays in the alarm state forever.

Now we follow the rounding rules used by AWS Autoscaling:

  http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AutoScaling/latest/DeveloperGuide/as-scale-based-on-demand.html

Change-Id: I79e5e743de1944ace5ef2c4dbcb76c9cab7262bb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/81/56281/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: def test_scaling_group_percent(self): # reduce by 50% self._stub_lb_reload(1) self._stub_meta_expected(now, 'PercentChangeInCapacity : -50') rsrc.adjust(-50, 'PercentChangeInCapacity') self.assertEqual(len(rsrc.get_instance_names()), 1) # raise by 200% self._stub_lb_reload(3) self._stub_meta_expected(now, 'PercentChangeInCapacity : 200') self._stub_create(2) rsrc.adjust(200, 'PercentChangeInCapacity') self.assertEqual(len(rsrc.get_instance_names()), 3)

subject: Update install.sh to reflect recent oslo.db format
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-13 16:55:53.000000000', 'files': ['install.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/4bd2d15b2146cf903361defc3d8541905c992ae4', 'message': "Update install.sh to reflect recent oslo.db format

The previous sql_connection option has been deprecated and replaced
with the database.connection option in oslo:

[database]
connection = mysql://heat:heat@localhost/heat

The old option still works, but the default is only respected from
the new option, which is confusing if you're relying on the previous
behavior where specifying nothing got you the sql_connection default.
So update the installed config to remove the deprecated options.

Change-Id: I0f5b4587358ec99b47c8ab3ee924191bbf2760a2
Closes-Bug: #1241826
"}]
commit_message:
Update install.sh to reflect recent oslo.db format

The previous sql_connection option has been deprecated and replaced
with the database.connection option in oslo:

[database]
connection = mysql://heat:heat@localhost/heat

The old option still works, but the default is only respected from
the new option, which is confusing if you're relying on the previous
behavior where specifying nothing got you the sql_connection default.
So update the installed config to remove the deprecated options.

Change-Id: I0f5b4587358ec99b47c8ab3ee924191bbf2760a2
Closes-Bug: #1241826
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/52/56252/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: iniset $target DEFAULT db_backend heat.db.sqlalchemy.api iniset $target DEFAULT sql_connection "mysql://heat:heat@localhost/heat"

commit_message:
A timing/profiling utility for savanna

Created a simple function decorator that allows for the given
function to be timed.  This will facilitate some profiling work
with the aim of improving the performance of plugins.

Implements blueprint simple-timing-profiling-utility

Change-Id: Ib5a85b053a6a09fbf5d2dd1fefe8a8163c5b18e5

commit_message:
Move tests into ceilometer module

Doing this allow for potential importing of the tests and is cleaner
than having a side directory. Nova already does this, so let's move.

Change-Id: I77fc9c5356f3962363fd355b8dbf44fbeec157ee

commit_message:
Fix server update attribute test

This is testing if an attribute not in the update_allowed_keys
results in UpdateReplace. Whilst this is true here, it's using
an attribute that is not a valid resource attribute. The only
valid resource attributes that I know of are:
(Properties, Metadata, UpdatePolicy, DeletionPolicy)

Just want to make sure we are testing the right thing.

Change-Id: Ic84239b0ff3960968293c2c367971f30d091e833
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/24/56124/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_server_update_attr_replace(self): update_template['UpdatePolicy'] = {'test': 123}
deleted_lines: def test_server_update_replace(self): update_template['Notallowed'] = {'test': 123}

commit_message:
Modifies CLI to show nodes by instance uuid

This patch updates the node-show subcommand for ironic so that it
shows the node that matches the given instance UUID.
ironic node-show [--instance] id
It also updates node-list subcommand so that it can show all the
nodes that have instance UUID associated or the opposite.
ironic node-list [--associated true|false]
This patch also fixes a few strings for i18n support.

Change-Id: I2aec9ba6e296e0d1db9f3ef9eed7236ecfb32cf6
Closes-Bug: #1239026
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient refs/changes/85/53485/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if hasattr(node, 'nodes'): # node was found by instance_uuid node_data = getattr(node, 'nodes')[0] data = dict([(f, node_data.get(f, '')) for f in fields]) else: # node was found by its id or uuid data = dict([(f, getattr(node, f, '')) for f in fields])@utils.arg('node', metavar='<id>', help="ID, UUID or instance UUID of node") @utils.arg('--instance-uuid', dest='instance_uuid', action='store_true', default=False, help='The id is an instance UUID') node = cc.node.get(args.node, args.instance_uuid) except exc.HTTPNotFound: if args.instance_uuid: error_tmpl = 'Node not found with instance UUID: %s' else: error_tmpl = 'Node not found: %s' raise exc.CommandError(error_tmpl % args.node)@utils.arg('--associated', dest='associated', action='store_true', default=False, help='Show the nodes that have instance UUID associated') @utils.arg('--unassociated', dest='unassociated', action='store_true', default=False, help='Show the nodes that do not have instance UUID associated') nodes = cc.node.list(args.associated, args.unassociated)
deleted_lines: data = dict([(f, getattr(node, f, '')) for f in fields])@utils.arg('node', metavar='<node id>', help="ID of node") node = cc.node.get(args.node) except exc.HTTPNotFound: raise exc.CommandError('Node not found: %s' % args.node) nodes = cc.node.list()

commit_message:
[bp] Add support for Cinder multi-backend

* Create class cinder::backend.
   Sets DEFAULT/enabled_backends

* Create define cinder::type.
   multip-purpose function to create type and optionally set extened
   information.

* Create define cinder::type_set.
   multi-purpose set function to set extended information.

* Copy rbd, iscsi, and nfs volume providers to support multi-backend
   Now provided as cinder::backend::<driver> to ensure that multi-backend
   aware resource is|[ not] used.

* Add rspec for new parts to ensure expected function.

Blueprint: cinder-volume-multi-backend

Change-Id: I6df9cadaad3b9ce2ab4b0e87dba9b5056459db10
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-cinder refs/changes/91/54591/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: **Define a cinder storage node with multiple backends ** ```puppet class { 'cinder': sql_connection => 'mysql://cinder:secret_block_password@openstack-controller.example.com/cinder', rabbit_password => 'secret_rpc_password_for_blocks', rabbit_host => 'openstack-controller.example.com', verbose => true, } class { 'cinder::volume': } cinder::backend::iscsi {'iscsi1': iscsi_ip_address => '10.0.0.2', } cinder::backend::iscsi {'iscsi2': iscsi_ip_address => '10.0.0.3', } cinder::volume_type {'iscsi': backend_drivers => ['iscsi1', 'iscsi2'] } cinder::backend::rbd {'rbd-images': rbd_pool => 'images', rbd_user => 'images', } cinder::volume_type {'rbd': backend_drivers => 'rbd-images', } class { 'cinder::backends': enabled_backends => "iscsi1,iscsi2,rbd-images" } ``` Note: that the name passed to any backend resource must be unique accross all backends otherwise a duplicate resource will be defined.

subject: Add a specialized Event Type model and db table
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-12 17:13:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/5a728d46d836b952f3c13d880618a87c867dc29e', 'message': 'Add a specialized Event Type model and db table

As the events API gets fleshed out and more robust,
it will become increasingly necessary to ensure that the
database schema modeling events has the ability to quickly
retrieve a list of event types. With the current schema
having a foreign key from event to unique_name (the
monolithic generic string key lookup table), in order to
get a simple list of event types, one needs to do the following:

SELECT DISTINCT e.unique_name FROM event;

Not only is this inefficient, but the readability of the
model and database schema suffers from the generalization of
the unique name field relationship. With this patch, a new
event_type table is added to the schema to allow for quick
and easy lookups of event types like so:

SELECT id, desc FROM event_type;

This will lead to future ability to categorize
event types with ease. Instead of adding columns to the
monolithic unique_name table, we would only need to add a foreign
key relationship to the new event_type table tying the event_type
to a future event_type_class table...

Note: this is a resubmittal of an earlier patch from Jay Pipes
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/41316/)

Change-Id: Ia57c2425d2431cea41c71904cb1d3511a4633aa8
Partial-Bug: 1211015

commit_message:
Add a specialized Event Type model and db table

As the events API gets fleshed out and more robust,
it will become increasingly necessary to ensure that the
database schema modeling events has the ability to quickly
retrieve a list of event types. With the current schema
having a foreign key from event to unique_name (the
monolithic generic string key lookup table), in order to
get a simple list of event types, one needs to do the following:

SELECT DISTINCT e.unique_name FROM event;

Not only is this inefficient, but the readability of the
model and database schema suffers from the generalization of
the unique name field relationship. With this patch, a new
event_type table is added to the schema to allow for quick
and easy lookups of event types like so:

SELECT id, desc FROM event_type;

This will lead to future ability to categorize
event types with ease. Instead of adding columns to the
monolithic unique_name table, we would only need to add a foreign
key relationship to the new event_type table tying the event_type
to a future event_type_class table...

Note: this is a resubmittal of an earlier patch from Jay Pipes
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/41316/)

Change-Id: Ia57c2425d2431cea41c71904cb1d3511a4633aa8
Partial-Bug: 1211015
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/63/56063/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class EventType(Base): """Types of event records.""" __tablename__ = 'event_type' id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True) desc = Column(String(255), unique=True) def __init__(self, event_type): self.desc = event_type def __repr__(self): return "<EventType: %s>" % self.desc Index('ix_event_type_id', 'event_type_id'), Index('ix_event_generated', 'generated') event_type_id = Column(Integer, ForeignKey('event_type.id')) event_type = relationship("EventType", backref=backref('event_type')) def __init__(self, message_id, event_type, generated): self.event_type = event_type return "<Event %d('Event: %s %s, Generated: %s')>" % (self.id, self.message_id, self.event_type, self.generated)
deleted_lines: Index('unique_name_id', 'unique_name_id'), Index('ix_event_generated', 'generated'), unique_name_id = Column(Integer, ForeignKey('unique_name.id')) unique_name = relationship("UniqueName", backref=backref('unique_name', order_by=id)) def __init__(self, message_id, event, generated): self.unique_name = event return "<Event %d('Event: %s %s, Generated: %s')>" % \ (self.id, self.message_id, self.unique_name, self.generated)

commit_message:
Fix URL for horizon in Debian

This patch fixes the URL for the Horizon dashboard in
Debian. It uses https, and not /horizon (but the root
of the server).

Change-Id: If12095b61ace9c5881e4421bdca042d9b5b8449b
backport: havana

commit_message:
"instance_usage_audit Hhour"->"instance_usage_audit_period hour"

In Point-2, change the command "openstack-config --set /etc/
nova/nova.conf DEFAULT instance_usage_audit Hhour" to
"openstack-config --set /etc/nova/nova.conf DEFAULT
instance_usage_audit_period hour"

The description about editing the
/etc/nova/nova.conf [DEFAULT] section has already been added by
someone else.

Change-Id: I978790c6a6c8d9a122ac972c6d3758a694645290
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1249779
(cherry picked from commit 69a73be10399e47b75d594f541b94ac433603201)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/16/56216/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Adds openvswitch-datapath-dkms package install for Ubuntu

Adds a note with troubleshooting information when GRE doesn't work
on Ubuntu 12.04 LTS.

Change-Id: I6223bbc0a0e77b1b0971ed52d7bbc7266d5fc69b
Closes-bug: 1249589
Partial-bug: 1238445
(cherry picked from commit fd01182026551015aa886d24ec5a9d68fde23b55)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/39/56239/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>Choose a networking technology to create the virtual networks. Neutron supports GRE tunneling, VLANs, and VXLANs. This guide shows how to configure GRE tunneling and VLANs.</para> <link linkend="install-neutron.install-plug-in.ovs.gre">GRE tunneling</link> is simpler to set up because it does not require any special configuration from any physical network hardware. However, its protocol makes it difficult to filter traffic on the physical network. Additionally, this configuration does not use namespaces. You can have only one router for each network node. However, you can enable namespacing, and potentially veth, as described in the section detailing how to use VLANs with <acronym>OVS</acronym>).</para> <note os="ubuntu"> <para>On Ubuntu 12.04 LTS with GRE you must install openvswitch-datapath-dkms and restart the service to enable the GRE flow so that OVS 1.10 and higher is used. Make sure you are running the OVS 1.10 kernel module in addition to the OVS 1.10 userspace. Both the kernel module and userspace are required for VXLAN support. The error you see in the <filename>/var/log/openvswitchovs-vswitchd.log</filename> log file is "Stderr: 'ovs-ofctl: -1: negative values not supported for in_port\n'". If you see this error, make sure <command>modinfo openvswitch</command> shows the right version. Also check the output from <command>dmesg</command> for the version of the OVS module being loaded.</para> </note> linkend="install-neutron.install-plug-in.ovs.vlan">VLAN tagging</link> modifies the ethernet header of packets. You can filter packets on the physical network through normal methods. However, not all NICs handle the increased packet size of VLAN-tagged packets well, and you might need to complete additional configuration on physical network hardware to ensure that your Neutron VLANs do not interfere with any other VLANs on your network and that any physical network hardware between nodes does not strip VLAN tags.</para> <para>While the examples in this guide enable network namespaces by default, you can disable them if issues occur or your kernel does not support them. Edit the <filename>/etc/neutron/dhcp_agent.ini</filename> files, respectively:</para> <para>Edit the <filename>/etc/neutron/neutron.conf</filename> file <para>Note that when network namespaces are disabled, you can have only one router for each network node and overlapping IP addresses are not supported.</para> <para>You must complete additional steps after you create the initial Neutron virtual networks and router.</para> <screen os="ubuntu;debian"><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>apt-get install neutron-plugin-openvswitch-agent openvswitch-switch openvswitch-datapath-dkms</userinput></screen>
deleted_lines: <para>Choose a networking technology to create the virtual networks. Neutron supports GRE tunneling, VLANs, and VXLANs. This guide shows how to configure GRE tunneling and VLANs.</para> <link linkend="install-neutron.install-plug-in.ovs.gre" >GRE tunneling</link> is simpler to set up because it does not require any special configuration from any physical network hardware. However, its protocol makes it difficult to filter traffic on the physical network. Additionally, this configuration does not use namespaces. You can have only one router for each network node. However, you can enable namespacing, and potentially veth, as described in the section detailing how to use VLANs with <acronym>OVS</acronym>).</para> linkend="install-neutron.install-plug-in.ovs.vlan" >VLAN tagging</link> modifies the ethernet header of packets. You can filter packets on the physical network through normal methods. However, not all NICs handle the increased packet size of VLAN-tagged packets well, and you might need to complete additional configuration on physical network hardware to ensure that your Neutron VLANs do not interfere with any other VLANs on your network and that any physical network hardware between nodes does not strip VLAN tags.</para> <para>While the examples in this guide enable network namespaces by default, you can disable them if issues occur or your kernel does not support them. Edit the <filename>/etc/neutron/dhcp_agent.ini</filename> files, respectively:</para> <para>Edit the <filename>/etc/neutron/neutron.conf</filename> file <note> <para>With network namespaces disabled, you can have only one router for each network node and overlapping IP addresses are not supported.</para> </note> <para>You must complete additional steps after you create the initial Neutron virtual networks and router.</para> <screen os="ubuntu;debian"><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>apt-get install neutron-plugin-openvswitch-agent openvswitch-switch</userinput></screen>

Need to run with root privs to create dirs under /opt. Then chown the
new dir under /opt to jenkins:jenkins so that the jenkins user can write

Change-Id: I1f3bc2226b0965a0d530a7a6070bdad5e0d84618

commit_message:
Actually create $BASE/new dir and set perms.

Need to run with root privs to create dirs under /opt. Then chown the
new dir under /opt to jenkins:jenkins so that the jenkins user can write
to that dir.

Change-Id: I1f3bc2226b0965a0d530a7a6070bdad5e0d84618
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/97/56297/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo mkdir -p $BASE/new sudo chown -R jenkins:jenkins $BASE/new
deleted_lines: mkdir -p $BASE/new

subject: Usage String has Positionals after Optionals
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-25 07:16:23.000000000', 'files': ['troveclient/shell.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-troveclient/commit/21a468dd3be820bcd83eb7b90b72f2ca48ad8530', 'message': "Usage String has Positionals after Optionals

print positionals before optionals in the usage string to help
users avoid argparse nargs='*' problems.

ex: 'trove create --databases <db_name> <name> <flavor_id>'
fails with 'error: too few arguments', but this succeeds:
'trove create <name> <flavor_id> --databases <db_name>'

Change-Id: I400c9f0ca5580bd287c5f3bcf935352e88071bc8
Closes-Bug: #1243981
"}]
commit_message:
Usage String has Positionals after Optionals

print positionals before optionals in the usage string to help
users avoid argparse nargs='*' problems.

ex: 'trove create --databases <db_name> <name> <flavor_id>'
fails with 'error: too few arguments', but this succeeds:
'trove create <name> <flavor_id> --databases <db_name>'

Change-Id: I400c9f0ca5580bd287c5f3bcf935352e88071bc8
Closes-Bug: #1243981
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-troveclient refs/changes/92/53792/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
from troveclient.openstack.common.gettextutils import _ def _format_usage(self, usage, actions, groups, prefix): """ Print positionals before optionals in the usage string to help users avoid argparse nargs='*' problems. ex: 'trove create --databases <db_name> <name> <flavor_id>' fails with 'error: too few arguments', but this succeeds: 'trove create <name> <flavor_id> --databases <db_name>' """ if prefix is None: prefix = _('usage: ') # if usage is specified, use that if usage is not None: usage = usage % dict(prog=self._prog) # if no optionals or positionals are available, usage is just prog elif usage is None and not actions: usage = '%(prog)s' % dict(prog=self._prog) # if optionals and positionals are available, calculate usage elif usage is None: prog = '%(prog)s' % dict(prog=self._prog) # split optionals from positionals optionals = [] positionals = [] for action in actions: if action.option_strings: optionals.append(action) else: positionals.append(action) # build full usage string format = self._format_actions_usage action_usage = format(optionals + positionals, groups) usage = ' '.join([s for s in [prog, action_usage] if s]) # wrap the usage parts if it's too long text_width = self._width - self._current_indent if len(prefix) + len(usage) > text_width: # break usage into wrappable parts part_regexp = r'\(.*?\)+|\[.*?\]+|\S+' opt_usage = format(optionals, groups) pos_usage = format(positionals, groups) opt_parts = argparse._re.findall(part_regexp, opt_usage) pos_parts = argparse._re.findall(part_regexp, pos_usage) assert ' '.join(opt_parts) == opt_usage assert ' '.join(pos_parts) == pos_usage # helper for wrapping lines def get_lines(parts, indent, prefix=None): lines = [] line = [] if prefix is not None: line_len = len(prefix) - 1 else: line_len = len(indent) - 1 for part in parts: if line_len + 1 + len(part) > text_width: lines.append(indent + ' '.join(line)) line = [] line_len = len(indent) - 1 line.append(part) line_len += len(part) + 1 if line: lines.append(indent + ' '.join(line)) if prefix is not None: lines[0] = lines[0][len(indent):] return lines # if prog is short, follow it with optionals or positionals if len(prefix) + len(prog) <= 0.75 * text_width: indent = ' ' * (len(prefix) + len(prog) + 1) if pos_parts: lines = get_lines([prog] + pos_parts, indent, prefix) lines.extend(get_lines(opt_parts, indent)) elif opt_parts: lines = get_lines([prog] + opt_parts, indent, prefix) else: lines = [prog] # if prog is long, put it on its own line else: indent = ' ' * len(prefix) parts = pos_parts + opt_parts lines = get_lines(parts, indent) if len(lines) > 1: lines = [] lines.extend(get_lines(pos_parts, indent)) lines.extend(get_lines(opt_parts, indent)) lines = [prog] + lines # join lines into usage usage = '
'.join(lines) # prefix with 'usage:' return '%s%s

' % (prefix, usage)
deleted_lines: #from troveclient import exceptions as exc #import troveclient.extension

subject: Don't use deprecated module commands
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-06 12:20:32.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/tests/test_migrations.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/2f62736e47367404ac56525689412d123d69c283', 'message': "Don't use deprecated module commands

The commands module was deprecated since version 2.6 and it has been
removed in Python 3. Use the subprocess module instead.
See http://docs.python.org/2/library/commands#module-commands

Closes-Bug: #1248216
Change-Id: I4091179c6b312ae8534b30adc518eff67d68320a
"}]
commit_message:
Don't use deprecated module commands

The commands module was deprecated since version 2.6 and it has been
removed in Python 3. Use the subprocess module instead.
See http://docs.python.org/2/library/commands#module-commands

Closes-Bug: #1248216
Change-Id: I4091179c6b312ae8534b30adc518eff67d68320a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/96/55396/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import subprocess proc = subprocess.Popen(cmd, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.STDOUT, shell=True) output = proc.communicate()[0] self.assertEqual(0, proc.returncode)
deleted_lines: import commands status, output = commands.getstatusoutput(cmd) self.assertEqual(0, status)

commit_message:
Xenapi: Allow windows builds with xentools 6.1 and 6.2

Building a windows VM with pre-installed xentools
6.1 or 6.2 requires device_id to be set on XEN VM record.

Requires xenapi_device_id to be set on the
image metadata, which is then used to set the device_id
on the vm record.

DocImpact

Implements: blueprint allow-windows-builds-with-xentools6-1-and-6-2
Change-Id: Id3cd9d569519f2df1afa046ddabf33f00d63c615

commit_message:
trigger devstack-gate test as early as possible

if we have changes to devstack-gate we need need to run this as
early as possible. So do this the second we've decided that
we need to run devstack gate in our project list.

Change-Id: I60464965a2e4cea5e1c85ea8833e98a8471fa5f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/30/55030/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function reboot_devstack_gate { export RE_EXEC="true" echo "This build includes a change to the devstack gate; re-execing this script." fix_disk_layout mkdir -p $BASE/new cd $BASE/new setup_project openstack-infra/devstack-gate master exec $GATE_SCRIPT_DIR/devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh } # Set this variable to skip updating the devstack-gate project itself. # Useful in development so you can edit scripts in place and run them # directly. Do not set in production. # Normally not set, and we do include devstack-gate with the rest of # the projects. if [ -z "$SKIP_DEVSTACK_GATE_PROJECT" ]; then PROJECTS="openstack-infra/devstack-gate $PROJECTS" # Also, if we're testing devstack-gate, re-exec this script once so # that we can test the new version of it. if [[ $ZUUL_CHANGES =~ "openstack-infra/devstack-gate" ]] && [[ $RE_EXEC != "true" ]]; then reboot_devstack_gate fi fi
deleted_lines: # Set this variable to skip updating the devstack-gate project itself. # Useful in development so you can edit scripts in place and run them # directly. Do not set in production. # Normally not set, and we do include devstack-gate with the rest of # the projects. if [ -z "$SKIP_DEVSTACK_GATE_PROJECT" ]; then PROJECTS="openstack-infra/devstack-gate $PROJECTS" fi# Also, if we're testing devstack-gate, re-exec this script once so # that we can test the new version of it. if [[ $ZUUL_CHANGES =~ "openstack-infra/devstack-gate" ]] && [[ $RE_EXEC != "true" ]]; then export RE_EXEC="true" echo "This build includes a change to the devstack gate; re-execing this script." exec $GATE_SCRIPT_DIR/devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh fi

commit_message:
Extract git_fetch_at_ref

The really dense logic in the zuulification of trees is actually
hard to understand. Extracting it into a common function makes
this much easier to understand the AND and OR logic of it.

Change-Id: I96f94da8901cd94772d1910d39b48270a45f73e6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/29/55029/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Attempt to fetch a git ref for a project, if that ref is not empty function git_fetch_at_ref { local project=$1 local ref=$2 return { [ "$ref" != "" ] && git fetch $ZUUL_URL/$project $ref ; } } if git_fetch_at_ref $project $OVERRIDE_ZUUL_REF || \ git_fetch_at_ref $project $ZUUL_REF || \ git_fetch_at_ref $project $FALLBACK_ZUUL_REF; then # It's there, so check it out.
deleted_lines: if { [ "$OVERRIDE_ZUUL_REF" != "" ] && \ git fetch $ZUUL_URL/$project $OVERRIDE_ZUUL_REF ; } || \ { [ "$ZUUL_REF" != "" ] && \ git fetch $ZUUL_URL/$project $ZUUL_REF ; } || \ { [ "$FALLBACK_ZUUL_REF" != "" ] && \ git fetch $ZUUL_URL/$project $FALLBACK_ZUUL_REF ; }; then # It's there, so check it out.

issue if we disable it.

commit_message:
Add received reviews to review stats

Add a new column that shows how many reviews each person received in the
same time frame.  It also shows the ratio between reviews given and
received.

As a side effect, the result now also includes those that submitted
patches but did no reviews.  I think that's still useful information to
show when looking at the heath of the review queue.

Change-Id: I936c65c91a76c3de6872da0f53a1fa10e3ca111e

sets were submitted during this time frame.

commit_message:
Add negative resize server action test

Test that we correctly fail when we try to resize
a non existent server.

Change-Id: I7f2523226c021fc04f0f807d79fb274844c59fae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/61/52861/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_resize_nonexistent_server(self): self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.client.resize, 999, self.flavor_ref) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate'])

subject: Revert "Removes generate_uuid from uuidutils"
revisions: [{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-13 21:15:34.000000000', 'files': ['tests/unit/middleware/test_correlation_id.py', 'openstack/common/uuidutils.py', 'openstack/common/context.py', 'openstack/common/middleware/correlation_id.py', 'tests/unit/test_uuidutils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/44e8222321f9043c96a8372a8044f738803ecbde', 'message': 'Revert "Removes generate_uuid from uuidutils"\n\nThis reverts commit 571a78a4bb17a753972e5ef90b0bbdff727fcfa7'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Removes generate_uuid from uuidutils"

This reverts commit 571a78a4bb17a753972e5ef90b0bbdff727fcfa7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/86/56286/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_generate_uuid(self): uuid_string = uuidutils.generate_uuid() self.assertTrue(isinstance(uuid_string, str)) self.assertEqual(len(uuid_string), 36) # make sure there are 4 dashes self.assertEqual(len(uuid_string.replace('-', '')), 32)

subject: Supports get node by instance uuid in API
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-23 03:07:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/c290a2804c97a54d9bd70698159f25bf3c10b586', 'message': 'Supports get node by instance uuid in API

The API needs to expose a means to search for a node, given an
instance uuid. This patch supports getting a node by an instance
uuid (/nodes?instance_uuid=<xxx>), getting all the nodes that have
instance uuid associated (/nodes?instance_uuid=NOTNULL)
and getting all the nodes that do not have such associations
(/nodes?instance_uuid=NULL). This patch fixes the ironic
part of the bug 1239026, the python-ironicclient part will be
fixed in another patch.

Change-Id: I40750f9a7fc91e87223bfcd72e17e25f4045359c
Partial-Bug: #1239026
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-10-23 14:51:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/1205c4c1b2738b2de282f75e6ab5b75504d84f34', 'message': 'Supports get node by instance uuid in API

commit_message:
Supports get node by instance uuid in API

The API needs to expose a means to search for a node, given an
instance uuid. This patch supports getting a node by an instance
uuid (/nodes?instance_uuid=<xxx>), getting all the nodes that have
instance uuid associated (/nodes?associated=True)
and getting all the nodes that do not have such associations
(/nodes?associated=False).

Change-Id: I40750f9a7fc91e87223bfcd72e17e25f4045359c
Partial-Bug: #1239026

commit_message:
RFC: Make _ more explicit by importing it

Some static analysis tools and new developers have trouble with the
magic __builtins__ method for accessing '_'.

Change-Id: I570021ec72b217e7cc3d1d65734a61adc096eba8

commit_message:
Style tweaks for Id3cd9d569519f2df1afa046ddabf33f00d63c615

Id3cd9d569519f2df1afa046ddabf33f00d63c615 looked good to me,
except for two small style issues: the hard to read testing dict;
and a doc comment which was more of a NOTE than a doc comment.

This review corrects theses issues without blocking the original
code review.

Change-Id: If4826fd7a282e75a567e56aae54aaa6f158b0594

commit_message:
Inherit org.openstack form of architecture prop

Also inherit the 'org.openstack__1__architecture' style of specifying
architecture on an image.

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/CommonImageProperties

DocImpact

Discrepancy between README.rst and nova help

2) NOVA_URL should be OS_AUTH_URL

commit_message:
Remove skips for bug 1182384

Commit a2ccca0 fixed some negative tests to check for neutron when
determining the invalid ID to use for nova APIs that behave differently
when using neutron vs nova-network.

This patch uses the same idea to remove the skips in place for bug
1182384 in the compute security group negative tests.

Closes-Bug: #1182384

Change-Id: I58ba125012a74ea49311a163e9bf7fd7af33c1fc

commit_message:
move nova v3 delete image tests into glance testing

There is no image api in nova v3 api. so move the tests
that just test glance into glance testing from nova v3
testing. The rest tests in compute.v3.image.test_images
just are the tests related to nova, like creating image
from a server. Also move the negative tests in test_image
to a separate file.

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api-tests

Change-Id: I42c0f08434de4a51d41f2fafd95cfaf72a9dd6da

commit_message:
Remove unused code in api/compute/admin/test_quotas.py

The 'tenants' variable is not used anywhere in the class, which should be
removed. Maybe it was ignored by someone when fixing something else.

Change-Id: I96eb4ff9590c6416c21d457e93075ddc74e5f3f3
Closes-bug: #1249804

commit_message:
Bump SWIFT_LOOPBACK_DISK_SIZE_DEFAULT over swift max_file_size

Swift is returning 50x error codes because its disk is too small, set
size bigger then max_file_size in an attempt to fix the problem, or at
least reduce it.

"we create a 4GB device, but swift thinks it can write 5GB, hence fail"
--sdague

This patch based off of Iccd6368e4df71abb5ccfe7d361c64d86e1071d35

Change-Id: Ib56a98cd74e7edf1fa90facc25c72632d43180f1
Related-Bug: #1225664
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/16/56116/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # if tempest enabled the default size is 6 Gigabyte. SWIFT_LOOPBACK_DISK_SIZE_DEFAULT=${SWIFT_LOOPBACK_DISK_SIZE:-6G}
deleted_lines: # if tempest enabled the default size is 4 Gigabyte. SWIFT_LOOPBACK_DISK_SIZE_DEFAULT=${SWIFT_LOOPBACK_DISK_SIZE:-4G}

commit_message:
Removes generate_uuid from uuidutils

As discussed at the summit, generating the UUID string seems
trivial enough to not need a function. Each project should define
its uuid generation helper function according to its required format.

Change-Id: I2689a5d810e1b7663bc6b77385b2913844c70b9e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/52/56152/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Revert changes before pulling repository

When running devstest.sh multiples times, it fails due to
changes in the config.json file made by devstest_seed.sh
script.

Reverting this changes before updating the repo, will allow
to rerun the devtest.sh script.

Change-Id: Ia0af95d51c0f0ddd66fa7324e7ea784cf3a6e6ce
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/34/56234/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: set -eux echo $TOOL_BASE if [ $TOOL_BASE == 'tripleo-image-elements' ]; then # Changes are made in the devstest.seed script. # Restore to original values so this can be rerun sed -i "s/\"user\": \".*\",/\"user\": \"stack\",/" elements/seed-stack-config/config.json sed -i "s/\"arch\": \".*\",/\"arch\": \"i386\",/" elements/seed-stack-config/config.json fi
deleted_lines: set -eu

subject: catch OSError to prevent breaking request /recon/diskusage
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-12 09:26:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/c050818f52406260fcf2fba82c7e9c10d2f72025', 'message': 'catch all OSError and return False in utils.ismount

User maybe face the errno.EIO when calling utils.ismount. The reason is
codes only catch errno.ENOENT and re-raise others. But in newer python
os.path.ismount implementation(http://paste.openstack.org/show/51930/),
codes catch all. So this patch catch all OSError and return False.

Change-Id: I5d9018f580181e618a3fa072b7a760d41795d8eb
Closes-Bug: #1249181
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-11-13 11:24:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/a3e3de398de4b8817fc7a738d4c83c38ea6b8ba8', 'message': "catch OSError to prevent breaking request /recon/diskusage

swift.common.utils.ismount maybe raise some OSError in some special
cases; and the request against /recon/diskusage doesn't handle it
before. This patch let output of mounted keyword is the error's message.

Change-Id: I5d9018f580181e618a3fa072b7a760d41795d8eb
Closes-Bug: #1249181
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2013-11-13 14:46:43.000000000', 'files': ['swift/common/middleware/recon.py', 'test/unit/common/middleware/test_recon.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/fd4843f8e72227318b1e2ee5fbd2d43cc3732a1d', 'message': "catch OSError to prevent breaking request /recon/diskusage

swift.common.utils.ismount maybe raise some OSError in some special
cases; and the request against /recon/diskusage doesn't handle it
before. This patch let output of mounted keyword is the error's message.

Change-Id: I5d9018f580181e618a3fa072b7a760d41795d8eb
Closes-Bug: #1249181
"}]
commit_message:
catch OSError to prevent breaking request /recon/diskusage

swift.common.utils.ismount maybe raise some OSError in some special
cases; and the request against /recon/diskusage doesn't handle it
before. This patch let output of mounted keyword is the error's message.

Change-Id: I5d9018f580181e618a3fa072b7a760d41795d8eb
Closes-Bug: #1249181
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/91/55991/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.assertFalse(utils.ismount(tmpdir)) self.assertFalse(utils.ismount(tmpdir))
deleted_lines: self.assertRaises(OSError, utils.ismount, tmpdir) self.assertRaises(OSError, utils.ismount, tmpdir)

subject: Stored metrics into compute_nodes as a json dictionary
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-07-05 08:30:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5002e750bdccfa74a62d88a20b238c6f4209e3ac', 'message': 'Added a new method to store resources in DB

The compute manager uses plugins to get the resource information of each node.
And then sends and stores in DB for the scheduler to read and do scheduling.

The patch adds a table [compute_node_resources] to store the resource data,
and reuses compute_node_update() API to update the information.

This is part of the blueprint utilization-aware-scheduling and the
blueprint generic-host-state-for-scheduler.

'}, {'number': 31, 'created': '2013-09-05 02:20:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1b019f1653b1c4514b36140df34cbed6f8d8606e', 'message': "Stored metrics into compute_nodes as a json dictionary

The compute manager uses plugins to get the metrics information of each node.
And then sends and stores in DB for the scheduler to read and do scheduling.

The patch reuses table compute_nodes and adds a new TEXT column to store the
metric data as a json dictionary.

The reason that we don't put those metrics into the compute_nodes_stat table
is because of the scale issue of sqlalchemy's joinedload(). For example, for
10K compute nodes with each node has 20 stat records, it takes more than 16
seconds for sqlalchemy to do the query to get all the compute nodes and their
stat information. Adding more stat records into the compute_node_stats table
would make it much worse. The JSON structure in compute_nodes table would
scale much better. And we could re-work the stats table into JSON structure
just like this metrics feature in future patches.

This is part of the blueprint utilization-aware-scheduling and the
blueprint generic-host-state-for-scheduler.

Change-Id: I4d20565567e9907cfcc92b1c1b15f3b35a806797
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>

commit_message:
Stored metrics into compute_nodes as a json dictionary

The compute manager uses plugins to get the metrics information of each node.
And then sends and stores in DB for the scheduler to read and do scheduling.

The patch reuses table compute_nodes and adds a new TEXT column to store the
metric data as a json dictionary.

This is part of the blueprint utilization-aware-scheduling and the
blueprint generic-host-state-for-scheduler.

Change-Id: I4d20565567e9907cfcc92b1c1b15f3b35a806797
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>

added_lines: from nova.openstack.common import jsonutils options(joinedload('resources')).\ options(joinedload('resources')).\def _update_resources(context, new_resources, compute_id, session, prune_resources=False): existing = model_query(context, models.ComputeNodeResource, session=session, read_deleted="no").\ filter_by(compute_node_id=compute_id).all() resourcemap = {} for resource in existing: key = resource['name'] resourcemap[key] = resource resources = [] for new_resource in new_resources: resource_name = new_resource['name'] convert_datetimes(new_resource, 'timestamp') old_resource = resourcemap.pop(resource_name, None) if old_resource: old_resource.update( {'value': jsonutils.dumps(new_resource['value']), 'timestamp': new_resource['timestamp'], 'source': new_resource['source']}) resources.append(old_resource) else: resource = models.ComputeNodeResource() resource['compute_node_id'] = compute_id resource['name'] = resource_name resource['value'] = jsonutils.dumps(new_resource['value']) resource['timestamp'] = new_resource['timestamp'] resource['source'] = new_resource['source'] resources.append(resource) if prune_resources: # prune un-touched old resources for resource in resourcemap.values(): session.add(resource) resource.soft_delete(session=session) # add new and updated resources for resource in resources: session.add(resource) def compute_node_update(context, compute_id, values, prune_stats=False, prune_resources=False): resources = values.pop('resources', []) _update_resources(context, resources, compute_id, session, prune_resources)

commit_message:
Allow spaces in quoted SSH command arguments

The check_ssh_injection() method was rejecting arguments with spaces
even when they were quoted, this was causing problems with some volume
driver commands such as commands for a storage pool with spaces in the
name.

Note that this backport also fixes a typo that has been fixed separately
in master with commit eb0f2e4dd538a79184efbb23d7e404147dfe877b .

Closes-Bug: #1244415
Change-Id: Ie4b809e1b39fdb752cf634e6d3c0a3924d8ac52b
(cherry picked from commit 2737c76cb2fb436f117a4f635aebca7a01691d88)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/62/54762/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Check for matching quotes on the ends is_quoted = re.match('^(?P<quote>[\'"])(?P<quoted>.*)(?P=quote)$', arg) if is_quoted: # Check for unescaped quotes within the quoted argument quoted = is_quoted.group('quoted') if quoted: if (re.match('[\'"]', quoted) or re.search('[^\\\\][\'"]', quoted)): raise exception.SSHInjectionThreat(command=str(cmd_list)) else: # We only allow spaces within quoted arguments, and that # is the only special character allowed within quotes if len(arg.split()) > 1: raise exception.SSHInjectionThreat(command=str(cmd_list))
deleted_lines: # First, check no space in the middle of arg arg_len = len(arg.split()) if arg_len > 1: raise exception.SSHInjectionThreat(command=str(cmd_list))

commit_message:
Extract setup_project as a single function

Extract the setup_project logic into a single function for clarity
and reusability.

Change-Id: I7ac3dd3f25b05487bbafc6a18242aa6c61f227c8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/28/55028/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function setup_project { local project=$1 local branch=$2 local short_project=`basename $project` echo "Setting up $project @ $branch" short_project=`basename $project` if [[ ! -e $short_project ]]; then echo " Need to clone $short_project" git clone https://git.openstack.org/$project fi cd $short_project git remote set-url origin https://git.openstack.org/$project if [ -n "$OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH" ] ; then OVERRIDE_ZUUL_REF=$(echo $ZUUL_REF | sed -e "s,$branch,$OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH,") fi MAX_ATTEMPTS=3 COUNT=0 # Attempt a git remote update. Run for up to 5 minutes before killing. # If first SIGTERM does not kill the process wait a minute then SIGKILL. # If update fails try again for up to a total of 3 attempts. until timeout -k 1m 5m git remote update; do COUNT=$(($COUNT + 1)) echo "git remote update failed." if [ $COUNT -eq $MAX_ATTEMPTS ]; then exit 1 fi SLEEP_TIME=$((30 + $RANDOM % 60)) echo "sleep $SLEEP_TIME before retrying." sleep $SLEEP_TIME done # Ensure that we don't have stale remotes around git remote prune origin # See if this project has this branch, if not, use master FALLBACK_ZUUL_REF="" if ! git branch -a |grep remotes/origin/$branch>/dev/null; then branch=master FALLBACK_ZUUL_REF=$(echo $ZUUL_REF | sed -e "s,$branch,master,") fi # See if we should check out a Zuul ref if [ "$ZUUL_BRANCH" == "$branch" ]; then # See if Zuul prepared a ref for this project if { [ "$OVERRIDE_ZUUL_REF" != "" ] && \ git fetch $ZUUL_URL/$project $OVERRIDE_ZUUL_REF ; } || \ { [ "$ZUUL_REF" != "" ] && \ git fetch $ZUUL_URL/$project $ZUUL_REF ; } || \ { [ "$FALLBACK_ZUUL_REF" != "" ] && \ git fetch $ZUUL_URL/$project $FALLBACK_ZUUL_REF ; }; then # It's there, so check it out. git_checkout FETCH_HEAD else if [ "$project" == "$ZUUL_PROJECT" ]; then echo "Unable to find ref $ZUUL_REF for $project" exit 1 fi git_checkout $branch fi else # We're ignoring Zuul refs git_checkout $branch fi } for PROJECT in $PROJECTS; do cd $DEST setup_project $PROJECT $base_branch cd $DEST
deleted_lines: cd $DEST for PROJECT in $PROJECTS do BRANCH=$base_branch echo "Setting up $PROJECT @ $BRANCH" SHORT_PROJECT=`basename $PROJECT` if [[ ! -e $SHORT_PROJECT ]]; then echo " Need to clone $SHORT_PROJECT" git clone https://git.openstack.org/$PROJECT fi cd $SHORT_PROJECT git remote set-url origin https://git.openstack.org/$PROJECT if [ -n "$OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH" ] ; then OVERRIDE_ZUUL_REF=$(echo $ZUUL_REF | sed -e "s,$BRANCH,$OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH,") fi MAX_ATTEMPTS=3 COUNT=0 # Attempt a git remote update. Run for up to 5 minutes before killing. # If first SIGTERM does not kill the process wait a minute then SIGKILL. # If update fails try again for up to a total of 3 attempts. until timeout -k 1m 5m git remote update do COUNT=$(($COUNT + 1)) echo "git remote update failed." if [ $COUNT -eq $MAX_ATTEMPTS ] then exit 1 fi SLEEP_TIME=$((30 + $RANDOM % 60)) echo "sleep $SLEEP_TIME before retrying." sleep $SLEEP_TIME done # Ensure that we don't have stale remotes around git remote prune origin # See if this project has this branch, if not, use master FALLBACK_ZUUL_REF="" if ! git branch -a |grep remotes/origin/$BRANCH>/dev/null; then BRANCH=master FALLBACK_ZUUL_REF=$(echo $ZUUL_REF | sed -e "s,$BRANCH,master,") fi # See if we should check out a Zuul ref if [ "$ZUUL_BRANCH" == "$BRANCH" ]; then # See if Zuul prepared a ref for this project if { [ "$OVERRIDE_ZUUL_REF" != "" ] && \ git fetch $ZUUL_URL/$PROJECT $OVERRIDE_ZUUL_REF ; } || \ { [ "$ZUUL_REF" != "" ] && \ git fetch $ZUUL_URL/$PROJECT $ZUUL_REF ; } || \ { [ "$FALLBACK_ZUUL_REF" != "" ] && \ git fetch $ZUUL_URL/$PROJECT $FALLBACK_ZUUL_REF ; }; then # It's there, so check it out. git_checkout FETCH_HEAD else if [ "$PROJECT" == "$ZUUL_PROJECT" ]; then echo "Unable to find ref $ZUUL_REF for $PROJECT" exit 1 fi git_checkout $BRANCH fi else # We're ignoring Zuul refs git_checkout $BRANCH fi cd $DEST

commit_message:
Shorten physical resource name to custom limit

The default limit for resources is 255, which is
determined by the column size of the name columns in
other openstack project databases.

The limit for nova servers is 53 characters due to typical default
linux HOST_NAME_MAX of 64, minus the '.novalocal' appended to the name.

The reduced name will consist of the following:
* the first 2 characters of the name
* a hyphen
* the end of the name, truncated on the left to bring
  the name length within the limit

The validation fix from bug: #1238272 has been removed.
Closes-Bug: #1250291

Change-Id: Iccaf905b2e73433a671559c49223c2b635402853
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/17/56117/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import testscenarios load_tests = testscenarios.load_tests_apply_scenarios class ReducePhysicalResourceNameTest(HeatTestCase): scenarios = [ ('one', dict( limit=10, original='one', reduced='one')), ('limit_plus_one', dict( will_reduce=True, limit=10, original='onetwothree', reduced='on-wothree')), ('limit_exact', dict( limit=11, original='onetwothree', reduced='onetwothree')), ('limit_minus_one', dict( limit=12, original='onetwothree', reduced='onetwothree')), ('limit_four', dict( will_reduce=True, limit=4, original='onetwothree', reduced='on-e')), ('limit_three', dict( will_raise=ValueError, limit=3, original='onetwothree')), ('three_nested_stacks', dict( will_reduce=True, limit=63, original=('ElasticSearch-MasterCluster-ccicxsm25ug6-MasterSvr1' '-men65r4t53hh-MasterServer-gxpc3wqxy4el'), reduced=('El-icxsm25ug6-MasterSvr1-men65r4t53hh-' 'MasterServer-gxpc3wqxy4el'))), ('big_names', dict( will_reduce=True, limit=63, original=('MyReallyQuiteVeryLongStackName-' 'MyExtraordinarilyLongResourceName-ccicxsm25ug6'), reduced=('My-LongStackName-' 'MyExtraordinarilyLongResourceName-ccicxsm25ug6'))), ] will_raise = None will_reduce = False def test_reduce(self): if self.will_raise: self.assertRaises( self.will_raise, resource.Resource.reduce_physical_resource_name, self.original, self.limit) else: reduced = resource.Resource.reduce_physical_resource_name( self.original, self.limit) self.assertEqual(self.reduced, reduced) if self.will_reduce: # check it has been truncated to exactly the limit self.assertEqual(len(reduced), self.limit) else: # check that nothing has changed self.assertEqual(self.original, reduced)

commit_message:
Enabled django-compressor for javascript sanity test

By default the test did not run with the compressor on
which did load the javascript. There's no way to test errors
compressing the javascript.

Fix bug #1187576

Change-Id: I1db226ae9709ff818e8d13b7935ded66c0f6eae3

commit_message:
Make file store writes cooperative

The filestore driver does not yield after each chunk
write which means that any other write threads/requests
must wait until the entire image has been written before
being serviced which may cause problems when multiple
requests happen in parallel.

Change-Id: Ib1369e1ad7e42a132822b42c7f886200dc714512
Co-authored-by: Hirofumi Ichihara <ichihara.hirofumi@lab.ntt.co.jp>
Fixes: bug 1247165

subject: Separate a deployment from a benchmark
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-28 14:40:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/9c1b81b07e0587c9c149fc6b8b1b75a191cd012c', 'message': 'Separate a deployment from a benchmark

A deployment was separated from a benchmark on several levels:

-   The Deployment model represents an installation of OpenStack. This
    model is related with the Task model through a many-to-one relation.

-   A set of operations extends the rally.db.api.* to store a deployment
    related data.

-   rally.db.deploy.Deployment is an abstraction of the data relating to
    the deployment.

-   DeployEngine provides an abstraction to manage specific deployment
    engines, control status of a process and handle errors. Very
    closely associated with the Deployment object and in role of a
    context manager controls its status:

        # Create instance of the Deployment
        deployment = rally.db.deploy.Deployment(config={
            "name": "DevstackEngine",
            "provider": {
                "name": "DummyProvider",
                "credentials": ["root@10.2.0.8"]
            }
        })

        # Performe of deployment
        with DeployEngine(deployment) as deploy:
            endpoint = deploy.deploy() #raised an exception

        # If failure occur into context of deploy the status of
        # deployment would be changed to "deploy->failed".

        # If some test broke the deployment e.g.:
        with DeployEngine(deployment) as deploy:
            ...
            tester.benchmark() #raised an exception
        # the status would be changed to "deploy->divergent".

-   The orchestration provides management operations on deployments.

-   Support of deployment commands into CLI.

In the current state CloudConfigManager is used by the BenchmarkEngine
to process a verification and a testing. But the deployment represented
as an endpoint (a set of parameters like username, password, project
and auth_url). The translation function was added to provide backward
compatibility between this formats.

Implements: blueprint independent-deploy

Change-Id: I8da5d6bfd969960ec452256dcf4a3bb21505e537
